description: Morgan Taylor lead manicurist Gina Edwards created a custom color with two coats of I’m Charmed and one coat of Sweet Surrender.
Suno Fall 2014
Jin Soon Choi created a neutral look using a custom color from Sally Hansen.
Cinnamon Bowser used a colorblock pattern with Zoya's custom colors created for Peter Som (available this Fall).  Source: Zoya
Lead manicurist Danielle Candido polished used Morgan Taylor Metaling Around to create dark gray nails.
Rebecca Taylor Fall 2014
Morgan Taylor lead manicurist Danielle Candido used Scene Queen and clear top coat for this blue-gray manicure.
Cushnie et Ochs Fall 2014
A Detacher Fall 2014
Julie Kandalec started with one coat of Adore-a-Ball ($9), then put on a base coat. Finally, she completed the nude nail with Allure ($9).  Source: Essie
Katie Jane Hughes layered Butter London Union Jack Black ($15) with a matte topcoat. Then used a striping brush to create red flames with Knees Up ($15).  Source: Butter London
Lead manicurist Gina Edwards used Impress Press-On Manicure in Superstar Scandal as a base, then made the scalloped design using Kiss Nail Artist Paint in Gala ($7).   Source: Kiss

Jin Soon Choi debuted a dark gray polish from her upcoming Fall 2014 collection with Tess Giberson backstage and used it to create a nontraditional French manicure tipped with Kookie White (available Spring 2014).  Source: Jin Soon

The OPI team used a bevy of polishes to create this sky and rainbow nail art. Shades include Can't Find My Czech-book (sky) and Alpine Snow (clouds). Plus, Push and Shove layered with Desperately Seeking Sequins (base) and Red Hot Rio, Toucan Do It If You Try, I Just Can't Cope-acabana, Amazon . . . Amazoff, Dating a Royal, and Next Stop . . . the Bikini Zone for the rainbow accent nails.  Source: OPI
Jin Soon Choi applied two coats of Nostalgia ($18) as a base and then topped the nude with one coat of Polka White (available Spring 2014) for a speckled manicure.
The models wore two coats of Maybelline New York's Bold Gold ($4) for a matte, metallic manicure applied by Honey.
Manicurist Michelle Saunders applied two coats of Bahama Mama ($9), plus Midnight Cami ($9) along the edge, to create this vampy French manicure.  Source: Essie
Miss Pop used painter's tape to create a thin inverted v-shape near the cuticle. Then she applied Licorice ($9) to the entire nail and used a paper towel to sponge on Master Plan ($9).  Source: Essie
Lilacism ($9) and Licorice ($9) were the two Essie used to create this design, which was inspired by American Horror Story: Coven. Source: Essie
Miss Pop created three different nail looks using Essie polishes. This shattered effect was a layer of Licorice ($9) with No Place Like Chrome ($9) drawn on top.  Source: Essie
Butter London's Marbs lacquer ($15) was used by Katie Jane Hughes to create this gold nail design on top of a Nail Foundation base coat ($18).  Source: Butter London

Butter London's Katie Jane Hughes poured Yummy Mummy ($15), Diamond Geezer ($15), Posh Bird ($15), Pearly Queen ($15), and Billy No Mates ($15) into a bowl and then dipped the nails for this marbled look.  Source: Butter London
Deborah Lippmann applied two coats of Naked ($19) to these long, almond-shaped nails.
Butter London Global Color Ambassador Katie Jane Hughes applied Goss nail polish ($15) as the base and then sponged on Posh Bird ($15) for a gilded finish. Source: Butter London
Essie manicurist Julie Kandalec used Berry Naughty ($9) topped with Matte About You ($10).
Maybelline nail artist Honey used Color Show lacquer in Pink Embrace ($4) and Dressed to Kill ($4) for this colorblocked design.
Nail artist Miss Pop used Ruby Kisses polish and monogrammed the nail using Kiss Nail Artist Paint in Gala ($7).
Manicurist Julie Kandalec used one coat of Essie Mink Muffs ($9) topped with Meet Me at Sunset ($9).
Custom nail wraps by Jamberry Nails.
For a flirty, feminine feel, nail artist Julie Kandalec layered on Essie Muchi, Muchi ($9).  Source: Essie
Vanessa Williams for Nails Inc created a custom pink shade for a sophisticated manicure.
Rita Remark for Essie painted on two coats of Allure ($9) and finished with a matte top coat for a clean, chic nail.  Source: Essie
Lead nail artist Michelle Saunders created a chalky beige with Essie Sand Tropez ($9) and Mademoiselle ($9).  Source: Essie
Lead nail artist Michelle Saunders painted on a coat of Essie's Ridge Fill Base Coat ($9) before painting on two shades of Allure ($9). Source: Essie
Deborah Lippmann used Naked ($19) as a base then created the white border using Amazing Grace ($18).
Rita Remark for Essie started with one coat of Sand Tropez ($9) then added two coats of Spaghetti Strap  ($9). Source: Essie
Pattie Yankee created a custom mirror finish for the Delpozo show.

Gina Edwards created this linear pattern using a base of Morgan Taylor Dress Code ($6) diluted with Stick With It ($6). The off-center stripes included Deja Blue ($6), From Paris With Love ($6), and Wish You Were Here ($6).  Source: Morgan Taylor
Butter London's Katie Jane Hughes painted a strip of Alabaster Gaze (available Spring 2014) diagonally on the nail then filled in the top half for an askew French manicure.  Source: Butter London
Jin Soon Choi applied two coats of Kookie White from her Spring 2014 polish line.  Source: Jin Soon
It looks like Winter white nails will be on trend for 2014.
Gina Edwards used Morgan Taylor Latte Please for the Thakoon runway. Source: Morgan Taylor Lacquer
Gina Edwards swiped on two coats of Morgan Taylor From Paris With Love.
Deborah Lippmann applied two coats of It’s Raining Men ($18), a classic red. Then she added Break 4 Love ($18) so that only a sliver of red showed.
MAC Cosmetics used silver and gold Mylar Striping Tape to create a frame border on the nails, and used Sunset Sky polish (available Fall 2014) with a matte top coat.
Gina Edwards created this manicure using Morgan Taylor Seal the Deal.
Miss Pop created this half-and-half manicure using part Essie Bourdeaux ($9) and part Licorice ($9). Source: Essie
Naomi Yasuda applied different levels of Essie's Aruba Blue ($9) to nails in a diagonal design for an unconventional French manicure.  Source: Essie
Gina Edwards polished nails with Morgan Taylor's Hide & Sleek, a dark blue that appeared nearly black on the runway.
Jin Soon Choi actually pulled from the moody tones for the manicure in Mica ($18). She kept the nails short and shimmery for a more modern interpretation of the dark romance theme.
Morgan Taylor's lead manicurist, Gina Edwards, used a dark red called From Paris With Love.

Essie pro Michelle Saunders created a floating bejeweled nail art look on the ring finger that included seven polishes. To get the look, open up a bobby pin and use the tip as a dotting tool. Dip it in the colors and make a series of polka dots that open up into a floral starburst pattern. The center is a glittery hue called Set in Stones ($9) that looks like a jewel. Source: Essie

Katie Jane Hughes started with Butter London polish in The Black Knight ($15) to the tips of the nails. Then she applied Diamond Geezer ($15) at the base. Finally, Stardust ($15) and the Anorak glitter (available in March 2014) went over the entire nail. Diamond-shaped confetti was the last step.

Katie Jane Hughes started with Butter London's Union Jack Black ($15) as the base for the "tweed" nail art. Then she used a striping brush to add horizontal and vertical lines in Billy No Mates ($15), Stag Do ($15), Blagger ($15), British Racing Green ($15), and Pearly Queen ($15). Source: Butter London
The main shade is OPI Nein! Nein! Nein! OK Fine! ($8) with a silver Designer Series Radiance ($13) tip and natural nail half moon.  Source: OPI

Tracylee and the Sally Hansen team debuted the new Fall 2014 polish collaboration with Reese backstage. Some models wore a silver and red glitter called Chili Flakes, while the rest wore a gray named Somber Bliss topped with Shattered Stars, a chunky metallic confetti.
Michelle Saunders used one coat of Essie's Spin the Bottle (available Spring 2014) for a nude look.  Source: Essie
Models wore a custom blend of OPI polish in Nein! Nein! Nein! OK Fine! ($9) and Alpine Snow ($8) to give nails a putty-colored finish. Source: OPI

Miss Pop used Essie Midnight Cami ($9) as a base and applied Good as Gold ($9) dots in a half moon near the cuticle and on the tips. If you don't have a dotter tool at home to re-create the look, use bobby pins! Source: Essie
Nails were done by Michelle Saunders for Essie and featured a soft pink look. She layered Cocktails & Coconuts ($9), Mademoiselle ($9), and Ridge Filling Base Coat ($8). Source: Essie
Nails were done by Michelle Saunders for Essie and featured a soft pink look. She layered Cocktails & Coconuts ($9), Mademoiselle ($9), and Ridge Filling Base Coat ($8). Source: Essie
Rita Remark applied one coat of Essie Penny Talk ($8) followed by one coat of Bordeaux ($9). Then she used a matte topcoat to mute the shine before applying a tip of Wicked ($8). Source: Essie
The Blonds Fall 2014
The Blonds Fall 2014
The Blonds Fall 2014
Naeem Khan Fall 2014
This triangular manicure was created with a Zoya polish called Sam by lead manicurist Sunshine Outing.  Source: Zoya
Manicurist Elle used Dermelect polishes ($14) to get the "moonbow" manicure.  Source: Dermelect
Sunshine Outing created a vampy look with two coats of Norra and then topped it with a high-shine top coat.  Source: Zoya

Zoya manicurist Sunshine Outing made a reverse half-moon design using Zoya Jacqueline (a nude) and Zoya Dahlia PixieDust (a textured black). The nude portion of the nail was also made matte to bring more attention to the dual texture.  Source: Zoya
Betsey Johnson Fall 2014
Manicurist Sunshine Outing used Zoya Claudine with base coat and top coat for a long-lasting finish.  Source: Zoya
Cinnamon Bowser used two coats of Zoya Norra leaving a half-moon clear near the cuticle.  Source: Zoya

Cinnamon Bowser started with a nude polish like Zoya Cho or Chantal. Then, a iridescent top coat was applied, Jane or Tasha. Finally the red accent was added near the cuticle using Zoya Sasha.  Source: Zoya
Deborah Lippmann used Take The A Train (available Fall 2014) as a base then added Glitter And Be Gay ($20) near the cuticle.  Source: Deborah Lippmann
Lead manicurist Cinnamon Bowser used Zoya's Art Deco Goddes and Peony Princess to create this neon half-moon manicure.  Source: Zoya
Get Inspired by the Nail Trends From the Fall 2014 Runways
